(omission of l) [a] "a male offspring". wed il-baqara ṯor 8 "a cow's male offspring is [called] a bull". [b] "... old". wed sebʕīn yom 9 "[you cut barley when it's] seventy days old"; wed sena 10,19,21 of lucerne, "a year old".
ref: Swahili wadi; Wright 2 204, where ibn/bint is used of people.

def: [a] 7,9,16,26 "an exorcism" (only held on Monday and Thursday evenings). [b] 16 "a party" at a wedding or a boy's circumcision.
"a birthday". pass.pt., cf. [404]. mālūd in-nebi 17 "the Prophet's birthday".

[a] vt 11 [730b],12 "to gather something together"; "to reconcile" people. Also + bayn, walleft bayn zog weḥarme 11 "I reconciled a husband and wife". [b] vi 7,17 "to gather together". minšēn twellef il-ḥarāra makēn wāḥid 9 "so that the heat gathers in one place".
[§ 4.6 example 1] of a lucerne- or grass-crop, "to be ready for cutting".
"to get ready quickly", e.g. for a journey. twellem! banrūḥ 11 "hurry up and get ready! we're off".
"to turn away from" (W), as in ḫallih! wallih! 6,11,19 "let it alone! leave it!" This phrase can attenuate into an adj. meaning "worthless, no good".

ref: R 187; W anna; H "... to grumble, complain (Syrian)".
R 229 teénne, 234 VI twāne; W taʔannā; L 3061 VI "to be languid, remiss ... flag".

def: =+ ʕale of weeds, "to crowd out" a crop. = [1156].
ref: H I, II "to throw so. into an inextricable difficulty ..."

def: [910c] "a wooden piece" held in a gāzra-ox-walker's crooked arm. Not wayl, as in Wilkinson 73.
[§ 4.6 example 37]; [1231] interrogative/relative pronoun "which?/which". wayš il-ḥāl? 20 "how are you?"
"a side-opening" in an irrigation-channel, lined with palm-fibre or cement, into which the miradd [588] fits. kill gelba fī-hē yitāq wāḥid 17 "every plot has one irrigation-inlet".
[1480]; [1375] [a] of animals, "a lower fore/hind-leg". [b] of humans, "a forearm, a hand".

ref: English? If so, not a new loan; for yārīn see [1288].

def: myessra 13*,17*,25* act.pt. f. Of a she-camel, [a] 13*,25* "noisily to want the male". [b] 1,17* "to be successfully served".
ref: [a] [128]; W "... to facilitate". [b] L 2976 of animals "... to bring forth or be ready to ..."
[893a]; R 201 "to become rich"; W "... to succeed, thrive ..."

def: variant of il [23a]. "to have". li-gmāl yilhe aṣal 16 "camels have class"; mā yilluh waqt mḥaddad 21 "[cassava] doesn't have a specific [planting-]time".
(pl.) riding camels. šellitna r-rukǣb ʕUmān 21 "the riding-camels took us up to Oman".

etym: A. Probably from ودع in the sense of abandoning, ر being substituted for ع. In دفر and دسر a similar substitution takes place. حَمُوه وَدَّرْت اَلشُّغْل = Why did you leave the business?

A. رَام = He sought, desired, attempted, etc.
اَنَامَا اَرُوْم آجِي = I am not able to come.
A. تجدّد in the sense of becoming new.
A. زَنَّي = He called (him) an adulterer or imputed to him) adultery. اِنْتَ زَنَّيْتُ = You abused him.
Same as above.
A. طَاع = He obeyed.
A. From رَابَعه = He took hold of his hand. خَلِّي الخَادِم يَرَابَعْه = Let the slave accompany him.
Omanee A. نَشَد = He asked.
فُلَان مُظَوَّل اَلْغَوَازِي مِن هَذَا الشُّغْل = So and so has accumulated a fortune from this business.
A. from وَكد in the sense of confirming. مُوه هَذَا الخَبَر وَاكِد = What, is this news accurate?
A. from تَقَدَّم in the sense of preceding, advancing.
A. from فَزِع = He feared.
1. A. عَقِب = after 2. A. خَلْف = after.
1. A. عَقِب = after 2. A. خَلْف = after.
A. غَادِي = a goer out at morning, i. e. early.
A. فَرِيضَة = anything appointed or apportioned.
A. نَوْبَة = a turn, time. نُوْبَة جَاء فُلَان = So and so also came.
A. دَوْم = Continuous, lasting.
A. from دَار in the sense of turning round.
P. تِيز = a fart.
A. from شَاف = He saw. كَيْف شيفَتْه = What is its appearance like?
A. فَلَج = a brook. In the case of a فلج there is a natural flow of water from a spring.
A. probably from غَيْض = sinking into the ground (water). This word is also employed to express a small channel for conveying dirty water from houses.
A. عَامِد = That which pursues, makes for, or supports.
A. سَاقِية = a canal. The سَوَاقِي are fed by an عَامِد.
A. حاز in the sense of taking land and marking its boundaries. رَاعِي الَحْوز حاز بَيْنَنَا the umpire arbitrated between us.
1 A. فَرْع = Derivative institute of the law. 2. A. See Arbitrate. بُولَك خُذمِنِّي بِالشَّرْع اَو بِالْفَرْع = Take from me your right either by (religious) law or by arbitration.
1 A. فَرْع = Derivative institute of the law. 2. A. See Arbitrate. بُولَك خُذمِنِّي بِالشَّرْع اَو بِالْفَرْع = Take from me your right either by (religious) law or by arbitration.
A. حَافّ = Dry (cough), or from بلد احْيف = a district or the like upon which rain has fallen.
A. دَارَى = in the sense of being fearful or cautious, the Omanee being evidently an extended sense. اَنَا اَعْطَيْتُه لَاجَل دَآريْت مِنُّه = I gave him because I felt ashamed to refuse him.
A. نَشَد = He asked, inquired. نِشْدُه مُواسْمُه = Ask him what his name is.
A. from اَغْفَى = He slept.

A. مُنَادَاة = a proclamation, convoking. 2 A. From هَرَاج. The Omanees make a distinction between حَرَاج* and مُنَادَاة, the former word being restricted to the sale by auction of property belonging to deceased persons only.

A. مُنَادَاة = a proclamation, convoking. 2 A. From هَرَاج. The Omanees make a distinction between حَرَاج* and مُنَادَاة, the former word being restricted to the sale by auction of property belonging to deceased persons only.
A. Probably from هَوْر = a flock, especially when numerous and tumbling one over another. لَاتَهَوَّر الكَلام = Do not talk much.
Compare P. بَرْش = Desire.

In a كُاَتِلىِ the side pieces are fixed into the legs which are straight; in a شُبْرِيَّة the top pieces are separate and fixed over the legs which stand at an angle, whilst stand the third kind is a large كَاِتِلي which a curtain-frame and curtain.

[unit for counting pieces of dried shark]

[unit for counting "relatively small, often rounded, discrete objects ... most medium sized fruits (such as oranges, mangoes and pomegranates), certain vegetables (including aubergines and tomatoes), small fish, eggs, tins of food, and other compact articles of a similar size". "The criterion for its application would seem to be that the article can be held comfortably in the palm of the hand. ... It would seem to be the equivalent of the Persian numerical classifier dāne, which likewise means a grain."]

literally, horn [unit for counting bananas, "and it would seem in northern Oman only bananas". Donaldson notes in a footnote:"In the Yemen, the same term qarn, though not apparently used for counting bananas, is employed to count bundles of qāt leaves (the mildly narcotic leaves of the shrub Catha edulis Forskål) wrapped in banana leaves, each qarn being of 10 smaller bundles (ribāt, sing. ribṭah, in Sahʕāʔ; habbāt, sing. ḥabbah, in Taʕizz) (Serjeant and Lewcock (eds.) 1983, 271a; and personal observation by the present writer)."]
Livestock in general, as in other Arabic speaking countries, are counted by the rās, pl. ruwūs ... Rās is used in addition to count cauliflowers and root vegetables such as carrots and radishes.
[unit for counting transported goods when the transport is hired]

literally tree ... used in the dialect of northern Oman to count large fruit ... The present writer noted it particularly in counting watermelons, though Jayakar records the term as a counter also for mangoes, while Galloway gives it as a counting unit for fruit and vegetables more generally.

If the livestock are caprine, ovine or bovine, a common counting term is the hāysha, the collective of which, hōsh, is the normal noun for goats, sheep and cattle in the Omani dialect (hāʔishah and hawsh in standard Arabic, both containing the idea of a large amount, a crowd).

A special term is used to count ʕuwāl (small dried shark), ... which even in the 1970s formed a very important constituent in the diet of the population in the interior of Oman and especially the nomadic population. The unit to count them is the lōḥ, ... pl. līḥān. Less remarkably, planks of wood are also counted by the lōḥ.

Another special term is employed to count strips of fish neeting. It is the ṭāqah, pl. ṭāqāt, which among Omani fishermen means a strip of netting of known width, the width being generally about 180 cm, 6 ft.

Imported wire (sīm), such as the fisherman have used to make fish traps since the 1960s, is counted by the handar, pl. hanādir, the handar being the roll. The term is probably a relatively recent introduction and must be the English hundred, since each roll contains a hundred metres (or possibly yards) of wire.
Human beings are frequently counted, as in Persian, by the standard Arabic nafar, person. [pl. anfār is noted on p. 95]
Collections of twelve of any object are often counted by the darzan, often pronounced darza, the English dozen. How long this term has been in use in Oman is unknown to the present writer.

Small bundles of items are counted by the rabṭah (bunch, bundle), pl. rabṭāt and ribāṭ. Various vegetables suitably shaped for tying (radishes, carrots and onions with their leaves) and small fish strung together through the gills are generally counted and sold by this unit. In these cases the number of items which makes up a rabṭah is typically five or six. The term is also used to quote quantities of qatt (alfalfa) and green barley (both used for fodder), and hanks of wool and of string and rope made from goat's hair, līf (date fibre or coir) or other fibres.

For liquids, the two relatively recently introduced containers, the tanak (literally tin or tin-can, and in practice the international standard can of 4 U.S. gallons, 3.33 imperial gallons, 15.14 litres), and the barmīl (the petroleum barrel of 42 U.S. gallons, 34.97 imperial gallons, 158.98 litres), are employed in counting quantities of fuel and other oils, and also locally produced liquid products such as fish oil and date syrup which nowadays re-use the same containers.

For liquids, the two relatively recently introduced containers, the tanak (literally tin or tin-can, and in practice the international standard can of 4 U.S. gallons, 3.33 imperial gallons, 15.14 litres), and the barmīl (the petroleum barrel of 42 U.S. gallons, 34.97 imperial gallons, 158.98 litres), are employed in counting quantities of fuel and other oils, and also locally produced liquid products such as fish oil and date syrup which nowadays re-use the same containers.

sacks; dried dates ... are counted and sold by the girāb, the sack locally made of woven palm fronds in which they are packed ... The term girāb, pl. girbān, is certainly the standard Arabic jirāb, sack, bag, but its use in northern Oman seems to be restricted to this very specific sense of date sack [mentioned on p.87,91,93]

In addition, several distinctive types and sizes of unglazed earthenware jar and pot are made in different settlements in Oman, each settlement with its characteristic shapes and styles, and it is probable that some of these were once thought of as standard units of count, and perhaps still are. General terms for them include kharṣ, pl. khurūṣ, which Lane records in his lexicon (under khars, with an alternative khirṣ) as a wine-jar, and qidr, pi. qudūr, a standard Arabic term meaning a pot. In Oman, the kharṣ is generally a large tall pot between 2 and 2 1/2 ft tall (60 to 75 cm) such as is used by the ʕIbrī nayyālīn, the indigo (nīl) dyers, while the qidr is smaller and squatter (6-12" tall, 15-30 cm) and is used in laban making, water cooling and cooking. Local names for different styles and sizes are also found, and these too are likely in many cases to have been used as counting units for the saleable commodities they contained.

In addition, several distinctive types and sizes of unglazed earthenware jar and pot are made in different settlements in Oman, each settlement with its characteristic shapes and styles, and it is probable that some of these were once thought of as standard units of count, and perhaps still are. General terms for them include kharṣ, pl. khurūṣ, which Lane records in his lexicon (under khars, with an alternative khirṣ) as a wine-jar, and qidr, pi. qudūr, a standard Arabic term meaning a pot. In Oman, the kharṣ is generally a large tall pot between 2 and 2 1/2 ft tall (60 to 75 cm) such as is used by the ʕIbrī nayyālīn, the indigo (nīl) dyers, while the qidr is smaller and squatter (6-12" tall, 15-30 cm) and is used in laban making, water cooling and cooking. Local names for different styles and sizes are also found, and these too are likely in many cases to have been used as counting units for the saleable commodities they contained.

Imported commodities in jute or hemp sacks, such as wheat, flour, rice, sugar and coffee beans, are generally counted by the gūniya, pl. gawānī. This term is not standard Arabic, though it is used elsewhere in the Arabian Peninsula, and the pronunciation gūniyya is also recorded. Because of the region's long trading relationship with the Indian subcontinent, and in particular since many of these commodities in sacks are imported from India and Pakistan, it is not surprising that the term should be derived from northern India (Hindi goṇ, Urdu gon, Sanskrit goṇi: 'sack', 'bag' (of coarse cloth) — cf. the Anglo-Indian 'gunny-bag'. The standard Arabic kīs (sack, bag) is also heard as a synonym for gūniya in this sense. The same two terms are used when the imported sacks are re-used to hold locally produced commodities, including locally grown wheat and barley, locally milled flour, dried limes (lūmī), dried sardines (ʕūm) and dried anchovies (qāshiʕ).

[pl. is noted on p.95] Imported commodities in jute or hemp sacks, such as wheat, flour, rice, sugar and coffee beans, are generally counted by the gūniya, pl. gawānī. This term is not standard Arabic, though it is used elsewhere in the Arabian Peninsula, and the pronunciation gūniyya is also recorded. Because of the region's long trading relationship with the Indian subcontinent, and in particular since many of these commodities in sacks are imported from India and Pakistan, it is not surprising that the term should be derived from northern India (Hindi goṇ, Urdu gon, Sanskrit goṇi: 'sack', 'bag' (of coarse cloth) — cf. the Anglo-Indian 'gunny-bag'. The standard Arabic kīs (sack, bag) is also heard as a synonym for gūniya in this sense. The same two terms are used when the imported sacks are re-used to hold locally produced commodities, including locally grown wheat and barley, locally milled flour, dried limes (lūmī), dried sardines (ʕūm) and dried anchovies (qāshiʕ).
a necked jar used primarily for storing and cooling water
a large wide pot used primarily for cooking

In the mid 1970s a potter at Saḥam on the coast of al-Bātinah was manufacturing pots in four sizes. In December 1974 his prices, which give and indication of the relative sizes of the pots, were as follows: gadawiyya 75 baias; talagī (perhaps meaning thalajī, a pot to cool water) 100 baisas; niṣfī 250 baisas; and khars ʕūd (ʕūd meaning large in the Omani and Gulf dialects) 500 baisas

In the mid 1970s a potter at Saḥam on the coast of al-Bātinah was manufacturing pots in four sizes. In December 1974 his prices, which give and indication of the relative sizes of the pots, were as follows: gadawiyya 75 baias; talagī (perhaps meaning thalajī, a pot to cool water) 100 baisas; niṣfī 250 baisas; and khars ʕūd (ʕūd meaning large in the Omani and Gulf dialects) 500 baisas

In the mid 1970s a potter at Saḥam on the coast of al-Bātinah was manufacturing pots in four sizes. In December 1974 his prices, which give and indication of the relative sizes of the pots, were as follows: gadawiyya 75 baias; talagī (perhaps meaning thalajī, a pot to cool water) 100 baisas; niṣfī 250 baisas; and khars ʕūd (ʕūd meaning large in the Omani and Gulf dialects) 500 baisas

In the mid 1970s a potter at Saḥam on the coast of al-Bātinah was manufacturing pots in four sizes. In December 1974 his prices, which give and indication of the relative sizes of the pots, were as follows: gadawiyya 75 baias; talagī (perhaps meaning thalajī, a pot to cool water) 100 baisas; niṣfī 250 baisas; and khars ʕūd (ʕūd meaning large in the Omani and Gulf dialects) 500 baisas
large in the Omani and Gulf dialects
1000 baisas making 1 riyāl ʕUmānī, was equivalent to £ 1.24 sterling at that time [1974].
dried dates, more commonly called siḥḥ in northern Oman
dried dates [more common than tamr in northern Oman]

Supplies of firewood brought to the markets from the semi-desert plains and mountains by camel or donkey are counted and sold by the akmah (or akamah, literally in standard Arabic 'hill', 'heap', 'pile'). As used in northern Oman, an akmah is a camel-load or donkey-load of firewood and seems to be confined to this meaning—or at least is employed with this meaning predominant.

The usual Arabic ḥiml/ḥaml, a load, pl. aḥmāl, was recorded during the collection of the field data as meaning a load in the most general sense, without the specific weight connotations found for example by Hunter in Aden in the second half of last century. The term in Oman could refer to loads carried by animals (donkeys, mules, camels) or by motor transport.

When transport has to be hired to move commodities, the unit used to calculate the fare (nōl) is the naqlah, pl. naqlāt, transparently Arabic from the verb naqala, to transport, but seemingly not used in the standard language in this Omani sense. One naqlah was reckoned in the 1970s as one sack of grain or coffee beans, or one large or two small girāb or tamr, or two cartons of imported tins, or any other object of approximately equivalent size or weight. An adult female camel (nāqah) can reportedly carry two (sometimes three) naqlah. In the early 1970s, when motor transport had already made its appearance in rural Oman, the cost of transporting a naqlah in a Landrover pickup as at most half the fare for one person and often rather less. [A footnote adds:] Though somewhat irrelevant to the present discussion, it is perhaps interesting to note that the term naqlah in Oman is also used to mean a counter in a fast board game played on the ground called hawālīs, presumably because it is transported around the board. The usual naqlah in this sense is either a date stone or a piece of dried camel dung.
unit used for counting "small to medium sized fruit"
unit used for counting "trees and large plants"
Twined wedding blanket made by Bedouin tribes of northern and central Oman. Characterised by broad horizontal stripes of black and madder-dyed red wool.
Thick pad of date-palm fibre positioned beneath a šdād maḍallaʕ to cushion loads and prevent abrasion. A component of the saddle system for pack camels.
Hollow silver elbow ring with incised or chased designs, filled with small stones that rattle when shaken. Worn by women on the upper arms in paired sets.
Green. Term used to refer to the first or 'green' stage of indigo fermentation.
Buoyant float made of karbah, the base of the date-palm frond.
Royal turban, of silk, braisim and metallic threads. Worn by the Sultan of Oman and members of the royal family for ceremonial occasions. Made by pit-loom weavers.
Biconical pendant ear ornament of silver or gold, suspended from a chain and worn over the ear by girls and women of Sur.
First stage in the development of the date fruit. See also nabt.
Chin-strap composed of multiple strands of silk, wool or silver chain, attached to triangular silver end pieces that attach to a woman's head covering.
House or shelter made of date-palm frond material (barastī).
[House or shelter made of date-palm frond material. Given as an equivalent of ʕarīš.]
A medicinal plant with purgative properties (presumably Convolvulus scammonia, a highly prized commodity in antiquity). Of south Arabian origin.
Yellow. Also used to refer to the second or 'yellow' stage of indigo fermentation.
Cluster of long flexible stalks to which the date fruit is attached. Used to make brooms and traps for wadi fish and birds. Single stalk šamrūḫ.
Black. Also used to refer to the third or 'black' stage of indigo fermentation.
Decorative lines of stitching on the man's dišdāšah.

Hanging jar of fired clay, often glazed or partially glazed and with a wooden lid. Used for the storage of honey or laban. Musandam var. kūz [corrected from kuz]. Small honey jars are also referred to in northern Oman as ǧarrah.
Acacia arabica. A leguminous tree, used as a source of framing timbers for shipbuilding.
Type of traditional Omani dhow. A double-ended Omani vessel of shallow draught, measuring approx 14 m in length, used as a fishing craft and for passenger or cargo transport.
Wind-catcher. A traditional Gulf architectural feature, in the form of a tower-like structure on the roof, designed for the ventilation and cooling of a building. Musandam var barǧīl.

Type of traditional Omani dhow. An ocean-going cargo vessel with a length of up to 40 m and three masts. Characterised by a transom stern with a high poop deck and quarter galleries, and elaborate woodcarving.
Bedouin tent of woven goat hair. Lit. 'a house of hair'. See also filī.
A general term for bracelet. Also, narrow silver hoop bracelets with die-stamped bosses or ridges. Worn by girls and women in multiple sets.
Lit. 'bracelet of stars'. Silver bracelet with large rounded bosses. Worn by women in paired sets.
Lit. 'bracelet of thorns'. Silver bracelet with spiked bosses. Worn by women in paired sets.
Type of traditional dhow, also known as šāḥūf. A long double-ended fishing vessel, measuring more than 10 m, used for laying out nets for sardine and anchovy. Powered by oar with a crew of 20-28 men.
Shepherd-woven saddlebag, for use with donkeys. Also used as a grass-collection sack.
Comb-like wooden tool used by potters of northern Oman to inscribe parallel rows of lines in moist clay. Also known as mišṭ.
Long-handled paddle for stirring ḥalwa, harīs, tabsīl dates and sugar-cane syrup.

Type of traditional Omani dhow. A graceful, double-ended sailing vessel up to 25 m in length, characterised by a long rakish stem-piece and a distinctive, high stern. Once in widespread use for fishing, pearling and trading.
Type of traditional Omani dhow, similar to a battīl qārib but shorter, at approx 11 m, and differing slightly in the sternpost.
Plumb bob. Used in construction and boat-building.
Woven pad fitted beneath a šdād katībī to cushion loads and prevent abrasion. A component of the saddle system for camels.
Bobbins onto which weft threads are wound, and which are carried within a wooden shuttle for traditional pit-loom weaving.
Man's overcloak woven typically of fine gauze-like wool with lavish embroidery of gold or synthetic metallic threads. Worn on formal occasions.
Stage in the ripening of a date where the fruit has begun to turn colour, but is still hard.
Traditional seasoning mixture of cloves, black peppercorns, cumin seeds, cardamom pods and cinnamon bark.

Type of traditional Omani and Gulf dhow. A double-ended cargo vessel, with one or two masts, measuring between 15 and 35 m in length. Characterised by a straight stem post set at a 45-degree angle, the end of which is painted black and bordered with a white band.
Rayon, a cellulose-based fibre of imported origin, used in traditional weaving. Also used to refer to rayon blends, which may include silk, cotton or synthetic fibres.
Omani incense, made from a range of aromatic ingredients including floral oils, fragrant woods and resins, musk, ambergris, spices and snail operculae.
Watchtower or other tower-like defensive structure.
Earthenware cooking pot, with or without glaze.
Face-mask, various styles of which are worn as part of traditional woman's costume.
Panel of lashed date-palm frond, used to construct houses, animal shelters and fences, and for the decking of boats, the drying of dates and other utilitarian purposes.
A clay oven used for rosewater distillation.
Traditional coffee pot. Silver, copper and brass dilāl are distinguished by narrow waists and long, downward-curving spouts. Pottery versions usually feature round bases for nesting in hot coals.

General term for bucket. Used in reference to small leather well buckets for the drawing of water by hand, and large leather well bags for the drawing of water from traditional zīǧrah wells in association with draft animals.
Large, lidded, oval-shaped basket of coiled desert palm, often covered with leather. Used by Bedouin women for the storage and transportation of household and personal goods.
Pit-loom side beam. Two such beams are used, typically hewn from acacia trunks and notched to hold two crossbeams.
Rotating umbrella swift made of palm-frond sticks. Used by pit-loom weavers for the preparation of warp and weft threads.
Finger ring comprising a silver band surmounted by a flat, chased disc featuring niello, granulation or chased decoration. Worn by women on the third finger of each hand.
Lit. 'arm'. A cubit. The basic unit of length based on the distance from elbow to middle fingertip, equivalent to approx 45-50 cm.
Generic term for a robe-like garment. Used to refer to both the men's and women's traditional dress.
Bobbin winder used by pit-loom weavers.
Pit-loom batten, a pendulum device which is drawn against the weft to tighten the woven fabric.

Large Bedouin necklace characterised by a rigid horizontal bar featuring silver, gold and coral beads, suspended from side pieces comprising multiple strands of silver ringlets, large beads and small rectangular huruz.
Water conduit. Also the collective term for a channelled water-distribution system.
A Bedouin term for the spindle whorl used by spinners (also referred to as raġwā).
Lit. 'jasmine bud'. An embroidery design of the Sharqiyah region, used on the cuff of women's trousers.
Variety of date with a particularly high sugar content, and containing a mahogany-red pigment. Used as an ingredient in indigo dye mixtures and depilatory mixtures for the tanning of leather.

Lidded baskets, made of coiled desert palm often decorated with leather by Bedouin women of central and northern Oman. Used for the storage of jewellery, aromatics, cosmetics and other personal items.
Bedouin term for panels of woven goat-hair fabric used to construct tents and windbreaks.
Diminutive handleless coffee cups used for serving Omani coffee.
Deep red, permanent pigment obtained from the roots and twigs of the madder plant (Rubia tinctorum).
Prosopis cineraria. A leguminous tree which forms open woodlands in otherwise arid areas, its roots extending underground for up to 20 m to access water sources beyond the reach of other trees.
Large bi-conical ear ornament of silver or gold with inverted, pyramid-shaped clusters of granulated or hollow balls at the nadir. Worn in paired sets.
Type of traditional Omani dhow. A large cargo ship measuring up to 35 m in length. Characterised by a transom stern, high poop, trefoil-crested stem-head ornament and elaborately carved woodwork.
Woven girth strap. Part of the saddle system for camels and donkeys.
Harness used to climb the date-palm tree, comprising a saddle (quffah) and thick, palm-fibre rope (ṣūʕ [orig. ṣuwʕ]).
Man's belt of plaited wool or leather, used to secure the loincloth. Also muḥablah.
Shed stick, used by Bedouin weavers in conjunction with the horizontal ground loom and inserted though the warp to separate those threads held by heddles from those which are free.

Finger ring comprising a silver band surmounted by a flat cut-out in the form of a diamond or hexagon, featuring niello, granulation or chased decoration. Worn by women on the third finger of each hand.

A general term for a bracelet. Specifically, a style of silver bracelet characterised by a narrow, tubular back and a flattened front section featuring incised, chased or gold-washed decoration. Also, simple hoop-style open bracelets or anklets worn by children. Also used for silver fetlock ornaments for horses.
Gelatinous sweet. Ingredients include starch, sugar, ghee, spices and nuts.
Leafy shrub cultivated as a medicinal herb on terraced ledges of Al Jabal al Akhdar.
Bedouin term for date-palm fibre pad used as cushioning for pack camels. Also waqī.
Bedouin term for a paste made from burnt seashell and water or camel urine, used to treat fishnets.
Silver or gold forehead ornament worn by young boys and girls and featured on the Bedouin woman's šabkah headdress. Also ʕallāqah.
Decorative fringe on a woman's head shawl.
Anvil-like wooden tool used by Batinah potters for shaping the base of the water jar.
Small chamber where a bride is decorated with henna.
Cardamom pods. Used for flavouring sweet and savoury dishes, and Omani coffee (qahwah).
Lit. 'ring' or 'hoop'. A general term for various ring-like components of weaponry, jewellery, camel trappings, etc.
Padded mat for camel or donkey, used beneath the saddle for cushioning.

General term for protective amulet. Specifically used to refer to rectangular or cylindrical amulet boxes of silver or gold, in which protective scriptures of Qur'anic verse are kept. Worn on necklaces and as hair or ear ornaments.
Three-tiered ornament of silver or gold, featuring a ḥirz. Worn by women down the back, suspended from the fastening of a necklace or from the hair.
Man's or boy's broad leather belt, often decorated with silver. Also referred to as a 'ḫanǧar belt' when worn together with the Omani curved dagger.

Man's or boy's broad leather belt, often decorated with silver. Also referred to as a 'ḫanǧar belt' when worn together with the Omani curved dagger. [Originally, ḥizāq and ḥizām were one entry, but I have separated them.—M.D.S.]
Lit. 'belt'. A Sharqiyah embroidery design used on the cuff of women's trousers.
A small dug-out canoe of mango wood, measuring between 3.5 and 6.5 m in length. Used for inshore fishing and for ferrying equipment, crew and catch between fishing dhows (sanbūq or šūʕī) and shore.
General term for jug, pitcher or other container for liquids, typically with a handle for pouring. Also a pitcher for holding water for ritual ablutions.
General term for a buckle. Used to refer to the ornate silver buckle on a ḫanǧar belt or a boy's belt.
Leather or hide bottle for medicine, ghee or oil. Also a leather bag for honey and ghee made from the skin of the spiny lizard (ḍabb).
Woody date-palm stem to which ʕasū and date fruits attach. The stems are dried and split for use in basketry production.
Attar. A fragrant essential oil obtained from the petals of flowers, used as an ingredient in the making of incense and perfumes.
Olea africana. Wild mountain olive, a source of wood for carpentry.
Thumb ring comprising a broad silver band with a vertical ridge featuring bossed ornamentation. Worn by women in paired sets.
General term for water storage jar, often hung from a rope tied around the neck of the pot.
Sheepskin. Used as a cushioned seat when riding a camel.

Type of traditional Omani dhow. A transom-sterned vessel with a distinctive vertical bow and a single mast, measuring approx 15 m in length. Used for deep-sea trading, coastal cargo-carrying, and pearling.
Dagger worn in Yemen, Asir and the Hijaz.
Basket used for the collection of dates, made from plaited palm leaflet.
Shrub grown in Al Jabal al Akhdar, the leaves and stalks of which are used to make a herbal remedy.
Male or female spirit. Not necessarily evil, although often held to be capricious.
The trunk section of a date-palm tree.
Small earthenware jar for medicine or spices, sometimes with wooden lid.
Firebox or brazier of wood or stone lined with clay, used for making coffee.
Triangular, flanged base portion of a date-palm frond. Used to make fishing floats, and stacked inside the šāšah fishing craft in order to provide flotation.
Winter house constructed of date-palm frond material.
Braided loading strap. A component of the saddle system for camels.
Large earthenware vats used in northern Oman for leather-tanning and indigo dyeing. Made in Bahla using coil techniques.

Omani curved dagger, housed in a silver-ornamented sheath, the lower third of which bends upward at a 45-degree angle. Worn on a broad belt by men on formal and ceremonial occasions. A recognised emblem of the country.
Style of ḫanǧar named after the royal house of Al Bu Sa'id, characterised by a studded, pommel-like hilt, and a scabbard construction inclusive of seven rings.
Large triangular ear ornament of silver or gold with elaborate dangles, worn in paired sets. Also referred to as mišillah.
Large earthenware jar used for storing water, dates, grain and other commodities.
Large basket, rectangular or square in shape, used for the storage and transportation of dates, dried fish and other commodities, and for the cooking of šuwāʔ. Made from plaited palm leaflet.
Hardwood derived from Artocarpus hirsuta, used in boat-building and carpentry. Imported from India.
Headstall system for a camel, comprising neckband (rubqah), halter (miǧḏal), rein (ḫaṭam jidāl) and nose-rope (ḫazāmah). Also refers to the halter used for donkeys.
Braided camel rein which attaches to the halter. Part of the headstall system (ḫatam).
General term for finger or toe ring.
Silver ring set with semi-precious amuletic crescent moon and stars. Worn on the fourth finger by men and women.
Finger ring comprising a silver band surmounted by a large, square-shaped cutout, often featuring a chequer-board pattern of niello or appliqué. Worn by women on the fourth finger of each hand.
Nose-ring. A component of the headstall system for camels.
Shepherd foot-pads of wool or goat hair. Worn in the mountains of northern Oman.
Double, warp-faced, Bedouin saddlebag for use with camels, featuring raqmā designs. Smaller versions are woven as horse saddle-bags. Bedouin var. ḫārī.
Single warp-faced, Bedouin woman's travelling bag for use with camels, featuring raqmā designs. Made to hold the woman's leather-covered travelling basket (darāǧ).
The bow portion of a bow-drill. See also miqdaḥ.
Thin braided nose-rope. Attaches to the nose-ring. A component of the headstall system for camels. Also a braided woollen head-thong used to secure a man's head-wrap.
Food mat, circular in shape with raised lip, made of plaited palm leaflet.
Pulverised plant ash, an ingredient used in the preparation of indigo dye mixtures by traditional indigo dyers.
Boat-shaped wooden shuttle, within which small cylindrical weft-bobbins are fitted. Used by pit-loom weavers.
Small leather pouch for money and valuables. Worn by men.
Curved, single-edged sword, sharpened on the outer arc of the curve, measuring approx 1 m in length.
Coil of plaited palm fibre used for the balancing of loads carried on the head.
Kohl. Black colourant derived from various sources including burned shark liver or coconut meat. Used to darken the inner rims of the eyes.
Cap for babies and young children, usually topped with a decorative tassel.

Man's embroidered cotton cap, characterised by floral, foliar or geometric patterns made up of tiny, perforated eyelet stitches on a lightly quilted background. The term is also used to refer to the heavily embroidered cape-like head covering worn by young, unmarried girls of Sur.
Cuttlebone, the calcareous inner shell of a squid-like marine mollusc (genus Sepia), traditionally used as a casting material by ḫanǧar-makers and silversmiths.
Buttermilk. Traditionally made by churning milk in a goatskin bag (sqā).
Henna night for women. Part of traditional wedding celebrations.
Pitch-like material derived from the lac beetle (Tachardia lacca), used by ḫanǧar-makers for seating the hilt and blade of the dagger.
Silver bar used as a medium of exchange throughout the pre-modern trading world.
Antimony. A metallic mineral used to darken the inner rim of the eye. The main ingredient of an imported type of kohl.
Fibrous material found between the base of the date-palm frond and the woody trunk of the tree. Used for making rope, and as a filtering and padding material.

Lit. 'board' or 'tablet'. Used in reference to a tablet-like necklace of silver or gold, suspended from a chain, often amuletic in character with Qur'anic scriptures and inscribed or chased designs. Also used to describe a camel shoulder-bone traditionally used as a writing tablet in Qur'anic schools. Also referred to as slayt.
Flat rectangular or square necklace centrepiece of silver or gold with stamped designs and dangles.
Rosewater. A fragrant distillate produced in mountain villages of Al Jabal al Aḫdar from the petals of mountain-grown roses.
Basket made from plaited palm leaflet and reinforced with rope. Used for carrying heavy loads.
Openwork-plaited clothes fumigator for use with frankincense or buḫār. Made from split palm rib.
High-firing earthenware with a natural temper of fine grit, used by Bahla potters.
Funnel, made of wood, clay, metal or coiled desert palm.
Embroidery term for running chain stitch.
The warp of a pit loom.
Drop spindle used by Bedouin and shepherd weavers of northern Oman for the spinning of wool, camel hair and goat hair.
The underground furnace below the firing chamber of the round, wood and brush fuelled pottery kiln (maharqah) of northern Oman.
Round clay kiln used for firing pottery.
V-shaped pad positioned behind the hump of a camel, typically woven as a companion piece to the saddle pad (bidād). A component of the saddle system for camels.
Type of small wooden or steel axe carried by men of the Wahaybah tribe in central and northern Oman. See also qaddūm.
Twined bait basket used by fishermen of the Capital Area and the Batinah.
Shallow iron dish with long handle, used for roasting coffee.
Sturdy strip of material sewn onto the saddle pad (bidād) and used in place of the saddle tree (šdād) for camel racing. [corrected from maḥši]
Main reception room or sablah. Also an outdoor sitting or communal gathering area.
Censer for burning frankincense and buḫur. Mostly made of clay although traditional designs are also replicated in silver.
Container of silver or copper of various sizes, often with a fluted lid, used for the storage of incense, perfumes, cosmetics, jewellery and other personal possessions.
Container for kohl, variously made of silver, leather, fabric or bone, with distinctive styles for men and women.

Choker-like Bedouin necklace comprising a rigid horizontal bar with a central bead of silver, or gold-leaf over resin, surrounded by beads of glass or coral. Side elements feature chainwork and a multi-tiered triangular hinge.
Rigid, tray-like basket of split palm rib, used for harvesting dates.
Thin, braided rope of fine black wool, tied around the man's headwrap.
General term for spoon. See also muġrāf.
Component beams (cloth beam or breast beam, and warp beam) of the horizontal ground loom used by Bedouin weavers of central and northern Oman.
Traditional wooden storage chest. Typically features two or three drawers, and brass ornamentation. Also referred to as ṣandūq.
Cogged wooden well wheel, used for drawing water. See also zijrah.
Warping mill, used by pit-loom weavers.
Heavy woollen cloak worn in the mountains of northern Oman.
Multi-tiered necklace of interlocking pendants with granulated decoration in the form of an inverted pyramid at the nadir.
Long-handled iron crucible used by traditional silversmiths.
Metal rod with a flattened tip used for stirring coffee beans during the roasting process. Also known as maqlā.
Small copper spatula used to cut ḥalwā into bite-sized pieces.
Narrow strips of flat braid, used in the embroidery of trouser cuffs of women of the Sharqiyah region.
Qur'an stand, usually of two interlocking pieces of carved wood. Also a Sharqiyah embroidery design, based on an X motif, used on the cuff of women's trousers.
Large copper cauldron used for the boiling of dates, sugar cane syrup, ḥalwā and the cooking of foodstuffs for weddings and other communal occasions.
Coral. Used to make beads and talismans. Traditionally obtained from Gulf and Red Sea reefs and through widespread regional trade.
Necklace of bi-conical silver beads with stamped or chased decoration.
Applicator stick for kohl, made of gold, silver, brass or wood.
Sisal (Agave sisalana), a sword-leafed plant of northern Oman. The leaf fibre is used for the making of rope, catapults and scrubbing pads.
Trap made of twined date-fruit stalks, used to catch wadi fish.
Drinking cup, often stored as a cover in the neck of a water jar (ǧaḥlah).
Lit. 'restaurant'. Hollowed section of date-palm trunk used as a feeding trough for cattle.
Brass cylinders with or without holes, used to sustain or extinguish the smouldering fuse of a matchlock rifle (abu ftīlah).
Small leather pouch used for the soaking of palm-leaflet material for making coiled basketry.
Rope used as a conveyor for clusters of date fruit during the annual date harvest.
Loading rope of goat hair or palm-fibre used to secure loads on pack camels.
Skein-winder used in shepherd weaving and pit-loom weaving.
Oval mat with heavy rope handles and raised lip, which is folded over and used as a basket for carrying infants and for the transportation of tools and supplies. Made from plaited palm leaflet.
Bedouin term for tasselled key switch. Part of Bedouin car trappings.
Leather bullet pouch with chased silver lid, worn on the ḫanǧar belt.
Arch or arcuated niche indicating the qiblah or direction of Makkah.
Man's belt with rows of vertical cylindrical chambers, used to store cartridges, phials of gunpowder and the man's cartridge-shaped kohl container (makḥālah).
Braided halter rope. Component of the camel headstall system (ḫaṭām).
General term for a container such as a wooden bowl used to measure grain and other dry goods, and also for cylindrical brass scoops used to measure gunpowder. Also ṣāʕ.
Large spoon of copper or brass, used for cooking.
Whisk-like plunger made of palm-frond sticks. Used by indigo dye-makers to agitate dye solutions, releasing the dye-stuff (indican) from the plant material. [corrected from miʕmāl | māʕamīl]
Leather bellows traditionally used by metalsmiths.
Sword-beater used by Bedouin weavers to separate threads as the shuttle is passed through the warp, and to tighten the weave.
Support bar for the batten (duffāf), a component of the traditional pit loom.
Drill-bit component of a traditional bow-drill. See also ḫūṣ.
A type of circular cast net, characterised by a mesh of 2-5 cm and a diameter of 3-4 m. Used for inshore fishing.
Heavy guide rope of date-palm fibre, used with the ox-drawn plough (hays).
Cylindrical basket of twined palm rib, used in the mountains of northern Oman for storing and transporting grapes, apricots and other mountain produce by donkey.
Headstrap, usually of silver, used to support ear ornaments, necklaces and other pieces of jewellery.
Gazelle-horn beating hook used by Bedouin weavers to align and tighten the weave. Also known as midrah.
Cloth beam. A heavy wooden beam around which woven cloth is wound as work proceeds. A component of the traditional pit loom.
Type of hardwood imported from Somalia, used for rib-work in traditional boat-building.
Weighing scales. Also a term used to describe the wooden harness support for the traditional pit loom.
Broom or brush made of date-palm frond or reed material.
Rosewater sprinkler distinguished by a globular base with a tall, narrow cylindrical neck.
Palm-stick 'needle', used for the seaming of plaited-strip basketry.
Iron-flint striker for abū ftīlah matchlock rifle. Also referred to as malbaq.
Key, ornamental or functional, of silver, brass, iron or steel.
Large serving spoon of copper or brass characterised by a deep, creased bowl and an ornate handle featuring pierced, incised or stamped decoration. Also referred to as malʕaqah.
Tongs of silver or copper used for hot coals.
Pulicaria glutinosa. One of several shrubs native to northern Oman from which yellow or orange dye is obtained.

Tweezer set of silver or steel with decorative chain. Often takes the form of a cartridge. Sometimes features chased or stamped decoration. Worn by Omani men and used to extract thorns. Also referred to as malqāṭ.
Mortar (mūqʕah) and pestle (safan), of clay, stone, wood or metal used for pulverising or grinding various materials.
Twined hurling weapon, made from plied palm or sisal fibre.

General term for dish or bowl of fired clay. Used to refer to a shallow dish for roasting coffee beans and small pots for heating milk. Also referred to as muqlī. In Musandam such bowls are also referred to as qadaḥ.
Variation of muqlā. Small bowl for heating milk or water, by immersing a hot stone directly from the fire into the liquid or by placing the vessel over a burmah or other cooking pot.
Wooden paddle used by Batinah potters together with an anvil-like knob (ḥiǧārah) to shape the round base of the water jar.
Bib of plaited leather embellished with silver worn by Bedouin women as a companion piece to the šabkah.
Man's headwrap of silk, braisim or cotton, made on pit looms in northern Oman.
Hollow, hinged anklets of silver with a broad, flattened section featuring incised, chased or pierced decoration. Worn by women in paired sets. Also referred to as naṭlah.
Rectangular wooden bobbin used by fishnet-makers.
Bird trap made of twined palm rib.
Calligonum comosum. Indigenous shrub, the twigs and roots of which are used as a source of red dye.
Fresh-water reed material used for mat-making in northern Oman. Also referred to as rasl.
General term for sandal, variously made of leather and plaited palm leaflet.
Bedouin woman's silver headdress composed of large sets of run ear ornaments supported by mišill. Also mišill al-rās [corrected from ras].
Leaflet of the wild desert palm (Nannorrhops ritchieana), used in the making of basketry and saltwater-resistant cordage.
Adze. Also used in reference to a small axe occasionally carried by Bedouin tribesmen. See also maḥǧān.
Openwork plaited chicken basket made from split palm rib.
Medium-sized basket used as a container for dates, spices, wheat and other dry goods, made from plaited palm leaflet.
Wooden pulleys for traditional Omani dhows.
Coffee, particularly traditional Omani coffee flavoured with cardamom.
Lit. 'writing pen'. A chasing tool used by traditional silversmiths.
Lit. 'moon'. Crescent-shaped silver bracelet, hollow with deep notches on the outer edge. Worn by women in paired sets.
Calabash or dried gourd of the Lagenaria siceraria vine used to make an oval bowl (ṭāsah).
Acacia nilotica, a leguminous tree measuring up to 5 m in height. Widespread distribution in Oman. An important source of wood for carpentry and boat-building. Seed pods are used in leather-tanning.

lex: qārib abū būz | qawārib abū būz
def: Type of traditional Omani dhow. A motorised cargo vessel of Suri origin, similar in size to the sanbuq, characterised by a schooner-like bow and transom stern.
Lit. 'horn' of an animal or 'tip of a mountain'. A term for the hilt of a ḫanǧar.
Openwork-plaited fish trap made from split palm rib or steel wire.
Type of copper vessel used in the distillation of rosewater.
Zizyphus hajarensis. A tree found in northern Oman. A source of wood for carpentry.
The direction of Makkah. Also a stone, niche or other marker indicating it.
Camel neckband worn for purely decorative purposes. See also rubqah.
Immature leaflet of the date-palm frond, used for fine, intricate basket-work.
Leather bag for the storage and transportation of water. Sometimes used in reference to a butter-churning bag (sqā).
Gunpowder flask of wood or gourd, often ornately carved, with brass stopper. [corrected from qraʕ | qruwʕ]
Toe cap (chape) of ḫanǧar or sword scabbard, typically of chased silver.
Wooden locking mechanism for traditional door.
Traditional wooden shoe, worn by townswomen. Sometimes with brass decoration.
Rotary quern used for grinding grains and clay.
Bedouin term derived from raqam (meaning 'number') and used for the intricate geometric designs in tribal weavings and camel trappings.
Ripening date fruit which is half red or yellow and half brown.
Jinn cloth used for the Bedouin zar ceremony, made by pit-loom weavers in northern Oman. Also used by the Bedouin in reference to a woman's mantle (sabāʕiyyah).
Sweet basil. A herb of remembrance, presented to the bereaved on the third day of mourning. Also used as a medicinal herb for the treatment of stomach illness.
Wooden support for the side beam of a traditional pit loom, usually made from the forked branch of a local tree.
A nut-like berry that is burnt and dissolved in water to make a silver-cleaning solution.
Neckband. A component of the head-stall system (ḫaṭām) for camels. Bedouin var. ribḫah. Decorative versions also referred to as qiladah.
D-shaped silver ear ornaments with pendants featuring inverted, pyramid-shaped clusters of granulated or hollow balls at the nadir. Worn in paired sets or as part of the nisʕah headdress.
Double-ended spear with wooden shaft 2-3 m in length, featuring a sharp iron blade and a blunt iron tip.
Fruit of the pomegranate tree (Punica granatum). The inner skin is a source of yellow or orange dye, used by shepherd weavers.
Woman's mantle or man's sleeping cloth, of silk, braisim or cotton, made on pit looms in northern Oman (see also ridāʔ).
Main reception room or maǧlis. Also an outdoor sitting or communal gathering area.
A general term for warp-faced rugs made by both Bedouin and shepherd weavers. See also šamlah.

Spouted water bowl of silver or copper with incised or chased decoration. Used for many purposes including the ceremonial washing of hands and coffee cups. Also referred to as saḥlah bu mirzāb or mizrābiyyah.
General term for dish or bowl. Used in reference to bowls of fired clay used for the serving of food and ḥalwā.
Straight-bladed, double-edged sword with a rounded tip, measuring approx 1 m in length. Often features silver ornamentation.
Three-channelled sword blade with flamboyant edge.
Elaborately embroidered and sequined woman's face-mask secured with a long tassel. Worn by townswomen in the past.
Tectona grandis. Imported Indian teak, used in carpentry and boat-building, and for making ḫanǧar scabbards. [corrected from aḫšāb al-saǧ]
General term for rug. Also used to refer to prayer mats of plaited palm leaflet.
An indigenous tree of the Acacia family. An important source of wood and fuel, particularly for Bedouin communities.
A talismanic necklace featuring a central disc of red or orange glass, or a plastic bicycle or road sign reflector set in silver with dangles.

Acacia tortilis. A leguminous tree measuring up to 4 m in height. Widely distributed in Oman. An important source of wood for carpentry and boat-building, and for fuel. Seed pods used in leather-tanning.
Small leather travelling bag used to hold water, milk, honey or butter. Sometimes used as a churning bag.
Sandalwood. Fragrant wood of various tropical Asian trees of the genus Santalum, used in powdered form as a cosmetic and an ingredient in Omani incense (buḫūr).
High-firing earthenware favoured for its resilience and heat-resistant properties. Found in Al Hamra and used by Bahla potters.

lex: sard | surūd Twine or cord of plied palm leaflet.

def: Traditional cement mixture of baked lime and clay-rich mud, used as both a mortar and plaster in Omani architecture.
Unbleached cotton fabric of imported origin.
Type of gill net used by Omani fishermen, with a mesh size of approx 10 cm. Used for tuna, barracuda and kingfish.

Lit. 'youthful'. A Bedouin term used to refer to the mask, worn by young girls, made from imported sheets of chemically dyed indigo cloth. Such masks typically have a metallic appearance and are gold or bronze in colour.
A type of circular cast net, characterised by a mesh of 1-2 cm and a diameter of 3-4 m. Used for inshore fishing of schooling sardine and anchovy.
Rock alum. A metallic salt used as a mordant by Bedouin and shepherd weavers to prepare wool fibres for dyeing. Also used in powdered form as a deodorant.
Bedouin woman's headdress of plaited leather. May be embellished with silver or gold bosses, discs, beads or coins.
Finger ring with pyramidal cluster of granulated balls. Worn by men and women on the little finger of each hand.
Finger ring comprising a silver band surmounted by a flat, chased cut-out, one end rounded and the other terminating in a point. Worn by women on the first finger of each hand.
Gill net used by Omani fishermen, with a mesh size of 8 cm or less. Used for small fish.
Gill net used for shark by Omani fishermen, with a mesh size of 15-30 cm.
Necklace of barrel-shaped or cylindrical beads, with or without spikes or bosses, strung together with additional beads or red glass or coral.
Man's sash of silk, braisim or cotton, made by pit-loom weavers in northern Oman. Zanzibari var mahsim.
Loosely woven udder bag used to prevent young camels from suckling.
General term for all warp-faced Bedouin rugs. A specific term for the traditional camel rug, characterised by narrow stripes of black and madder-dyed red. Also known as sahah or sajjadah.

Bedouin hair ornament worn on the back of the head. Made of plaited leather embellished with silver or gold bosses or discs, and beads of glass or coral. Also, single stalk to which the date fruit is attached. See also ʕasū.
Neem tree (Azadirachta indica), a tall, usually evergreen, East Indian tree.
Lit. 'East-West'. An embroidery term for a herring-bone stitch used in the embroidery of the women's costume of the Sharqiyah.
Traditional fishing craft of the Batinah coast constructed of lashed date-palm frond, and measuring 4-6 m in length.
Food cover, conical in shape, made of plaited or coiled palm leaflet or of clay.
Lit. 'thorn'. Brooch of silver or gold, usually circular or diamond-shaped, used to secure the headscarf. Also, the pointed bosses of the banjirī bracelet.
Lit. 'silver thorn'. Multi-purpose ornamental pick of silver, brass or steel.

General term for wooden saddle-tree, sometimes featuring carved decoration, used as the anchoring point for various trappings and loading straps for camels. The term is also used for wooden saddles for donkeys.
Small wooden saddle-tree, often carved, used when travelling by camel and for ceremonial events. A component of the saddle system.
Large wooden saddle-tree. A component of the saddle system for pack camels.
Embroidery term for Bedouin variation of chain stitch.
Shield-shaped 'tulchan' of calf-skin over a wooden frame. Used to encourage milk production in cows after calving.
Lit. 'Jaalan style'. An embroidery design of the Sharqiyah region, used on the cuff of women's trousers.
An edging of herring-bone stitches used on the embroidered cuff of women's trousers.

Bib-like Bedouin necklace of gold-washed silver with glass or coral beads, comprising a series of horizontal bars with flat interconnecting pieces in the form of diamonds and elongated hexagons. Worn suspended from a mišill, often in combination with ġalāmiyyah ear ornaments. Bedouin variant is šibāq.

Type of traditional Omani dhow once used as a coastal cargo carrier, now used almost exclusively for fishing. Similar in style to the sanbūq, although smaller, with a straight rather than a curved stem piece. Continues to be built in Sur, Ayjah and Al Ashkhara. Also referred to as lanš.
Traditional Omani delicacy of goat meat, wrapped in banana leaves, sealed in a woven palm bag and roasted in a covered pit lined with stones.
Zizyphus spina-christi. Shrub or tree widely distributed in Oman. An important source of wood for carpentry and boat-building. Underbark used as a traditional red dyestuff. Small edible fruits.
Small basket made of split palm rib, with or without lid, used for the storage of a woman's sewing equipment, cosmetics and other personal possessions. Also a winnowing basket.
Curved knife used by leather-tanners to remove hair from hide.
Long, sharp spines found at the base of the date-palm frond. Used by basket-makers to split palm leaflets, and by kummah embroiderers to make eyelet holes in the man's cap.
Sitting and sleeping mat, rectangular in shape, made of plaited palm leaflet.
Round food-serving tray, often of copper with chased or incised decoration. Typically 50 cm in diameter, although ceremonial versions can be much larger.
Long, thin leather strands, used in the embellishment of Bedouin basketry, or plaited into flat bands or round cords for the making of the traditional Bedouin headdress (šabkah).
Woman's trousers, typically featuring heavily embroidered cuffs.
Leather bag for the churning of butter and laban.
Decorative silver breast strap for a horse, or a woven breast strap for a camel.
Plaited strip of palm leaflet, seamed edge to edge, folded or overstitched to form baskets and other palm products.

Flat silver disc, worn suspended on a chain or as the centrepiece of a large necklace. Variously decorated with geometric designs, niello-work or Qur'anic inscriptions. May feature a small inscribed figure on the back representing a captive jinni as an emblem of protection for the wearer. A disc inscribed with calligraphy is also referred to as a qirš kitāb. Bedouin var. ḥanḥūn.
Lit. 'the dark soug'. The great shaded soug at Muttrah.
Thick, palm-fibre rope. A component of the date-palm climbing harness (ḥabl al-ṭulūʕ). [corrected from ṣuwʕ]

Type of hand spindle used by traditional pit-loom weavers for winding weft threads onto bobbins, which is weighted with a circular stone whorl positioned on the top of the spindle shaft, and rotated in a half-coconut shell or cup base.
Bedouin term for tasselled, woven dashboard cover. Part of Bedouin car trappings.
Date-boiling season commencing in June, when date fruits begin to turn from green to bright yellow or red.
Embroidery term for Bedouin variation of blanket stitch.
'Temple' of crossed palm sticks, used by pit-loom weavers to keep the cloth stretched to the correct width while weaving.
Breech-loading rifle such as Belgium Liege, Martini Henri or Lee Enfield, often with silver or gold ornamentation on the stock and barrel. Also referred to as bunduqiyyah.
Woven rump strap for donkey. Part of the saddling and loading system for riding and for the transportation of goods.
Small bag or pouch made from plaited palm leaflet, traditionally used for the packaging of ḥalwā, [Was text accidentally lost here? Check in the text of the book to append this entry.]
Encircling bands of silver on a sword scabbard.
Handmade trim consisting of a strip of foil within a framework of braided cotton threads. Used to embellish women's costumes in northern Oman. Also known as sīm.
Flat wooden sizing or 'mesh' stick used by fishnet-makers to ensure consistency in mesh size and to determine the gauge of a net.
Brass or wooden measuring scoops for gunpowder.

Oval bowl or drinking vessel of copper, often with incised decoration. Also made from dried gourds (qaraʕ yābis [corrected from qaraʕ yābīs]). Sometimes referred to as saḥlah [corrected from ṣahlah].
Talisman of silver or gold in the form of a stylised human figure. Worn mainly by children on a simple chain around the neck.
General term for embroidery or needlework.
Lit. 'enrobed leg'. Sharqiyah embroidery design, used on the cuff of women's trousers.
Large donkey pannier made from plaited palm leaflet.
A clay oven used to boil raw dates.
Silver collar, approx 2-3 cm deep, within which the hilt and blade of the Omani curved dagger (ḫanǧar) are seated.
Parrying shield, traditionally made of rhinoceros or hippopotamus hide, or shark skin, but also of wood or leather-covered, coiled desert palm. A companion piece to swords.
Fragrant aloe wood used in Omani incense mixtures (buḫūr).
Talismanic objects set in silver and worn on necklaces to protect the wearer from harm.
Decorative terminal tassel on the cord used to affix the Bedouin face-mask.
Indigo plant. Pigment-yielding shrub of the genus Indigofera, numerous species of which are indigenous to Oman.
Wooden yoke used with draught animals.
Rose. Fragrant blossoms of the genus Rosa.
Man's loincloth, worn under the dišdāšah.
Embroidered neck opening on a dišdāšah.
Fragrant myrtle shrub (Myrtus communis) having small aromatic leaves which are used in herbal and cosmetic mixtures.
Of or relating to the jinn as in the Bedouin zār ceremony in which the jinn are consulted. Also used for various articles worn for talismanic value, including belts and finger rings.
Knitted Bedouin sand-socks of wool or goat hair.
Date-palm frond. Used in its entirety as a construction material. Leaflets, central rib, flanged base and spines are also used separately.
Saffron, a flavouring and colourant derived from the stamens of the crocus flower (Crocus sativus). Used in Omani coffee, halwa and as a cosmetic for Bedouin women.
Also commonly zayǧrah | zayǧrāt. Traditional well. Characterised by a massive wooden framework, often of date-palm trunks, with a crossbar on which rotates a cogged well wheel (manǧūr).
Tasselled, woven dashboard panel. Part of Bedouin car trappings.
Cross beams for a traditional pit loom.
Secondary girth strap used especially for racing camels.
An incense ingredient with fixative properties, derived from dried snail operculae. Used in the preparation of Omani buḫur.
Itinerant smiths, locally referred to as gypsies, who travelled from town to town attending to metalworking and other tasks.
Embroidery design comprising four or more rhomboids connected point to point, featured on the Suri man's dišdāšah.
Embroidery term for Suri variation of herring-bone stitch.
Forehead piece of silver or gold with coral beads or pearls, worn by young, unmarried girls, especially in Dhofar.

Conical, tassel-like silver or gold hair ornaments, worn by Dhofari girls and women at the end of hair plaits in sets of six, eight or ten. Also made of leather decorated with cowries or small glass beads.
Leather bag or satchel for storage of dry goods. Also referred to in Dhofar as ʕanit. The term habbān is also used for decorative leather tobacco pouches used by Dhofari tribesmen.
Olive shell (Oliva bulbosa). Used as a burnishing tool by potters in Dhofar.
Small spouted cup of fired clay used for feeding infants in Dhofar. Also muǧrū.
Lengths of silver chain used as a component of Dhofari jewellery and embroidery.
Red-earth pigment, used by Dhofari potters for the decoration of burnished terracotta ware.
Silver anklets with decorative chain work and bells or dangles. Often embellished with glass and coral beads. Worn by married women in Dhofar especially for dancing.
Camel. Also used to describe terracotta camel figurines made by potters in Dhofar.

Lit. 'of the mountains'. A colloquial, collective term for the tribal inhabitants of the mountains of Dhofar. Technically, a reference to the language most commonly spoken by these tribes, one of a group of non-Arabic languages of South Arabian origin.
General term for a muzzle of plied palm fibre or other rope, used on camels to prevent grazing. Also referred to as faṭāmah in Dhofar, or as liṯāmah by Bedouin communities.

A general term for bowl-like baskets of coiled desert palm covered or decorated with leather. A specific term for leather-covered bowls used for the milking of camels or goats. Also referred to in Dhofar as ġariyyah.
Dhofari woman's headdress, of cotton with silver and embroidered decoration, characterised by two parallel padded ridges of cloth running from front to back. Worn at weddings and festivals.
Frankincense. A resinous gum derived from Boswellia sacra, a tree native to Dhofar. Burned as an aromatic and fumigant, and as a medicinal or religious purifier.
Wooden tongs for handling hot stones, which are placed in milk pots to bring the milk to the boil. Used in Dhofar.
Tobacco pipe, variously made of silver, stone, clay or wood. Dhofari var fiǧīr.
Small pot of fired clay, with handle and spout, traditionally used by women in Dhofar for sniffing ghee into the nasal passages for cosmetic purposes.
Clam shell of the Veneridae family, used as a shaping tool by Dhofari potters.
Silver bracelet of polygonal, granulated and coral beads. Worn in paired sets by women in Dhofar.
Metal bodkin or awl, used as a shredding and piercing tool in coiled Bedouin basketry. Also used as a boring tool by Dhofari pipe-makers.
Silver chain worn by Dhofari women diagonally across the chest and over one shoulder, under the clothing. Also, a silver belt worn by Dhofari men around the waist or diagonally across the chest.
Portable baby cot of goat hide stretched over a wooden frame. Also referred to as haddah or ḥaddah in Dhofar.
Whisk or fan made of plaited palm leaflet. Also referred to as mšabbah, in northern Oman, and as mirawḥah in Dhofar.
Local term for spatulate knife used for the harvesting of frankincense in Dhofar.
Local term for circular cultivated fields ringed with stone walls in the mountains of Dhofar.
Toe ring of twisted silver wire. Worn by women in Dhofar.
D-shaped bracelet of twisted silver, worn in paired sets by the women of Dhofar.
Style of embroidery used in Dhofar for the decoration of the women's ṯawb, combining threadwork and silverwork.

Lit. 'star'. Small silver hemispheres stitched onto leather headdresses (šabkah) in northern and central Oman, and onto women's costume in Dhofar. Also refers to the tiny perforations in a man's cap (kummah) and the brass studs on an Omani chest (mandūs).

Burnt and pulverised limestone used as an additive in indigo dye mixtures, and in the making of traditional mortar and plaster (ṣārūǧ). Also limestone or chalk, used for the carving of pipes in Dhofar.

A heavy stone kick wheel used by potters of northern Oman. Also used in reference to a disc-shaped press of fired clay with incised designs, used by women in Dhofar to pattern the surface of bread prior to baking. Also a mould for the casting of lead bullets.
Oil lamp. Used to refer to lamps of fired clay made in Dhofar. Also referred to as sirāǧ.

General term for basket. Used in Dhofar in reference to salt baskets, bread baskets and other containers made of plaited palm leaflet. Also used to refer to the saddle portion of the date-palm climbing harness (ḥabl al-ṭulūʕ).
Small roulette of copper wire wrapped around a metal ring. Used as an impressing tool for the decoration of pottery in Dhofar.
Dried juice of Aloe dhufarensis. Used in Dhofar as a cosmetic and as a yellow-orange pigment for the decoration of pottery.
Clarified butter (ghee) or rendered animal fat. Used as a burnishing lubricant by Dhofari potters.

Type of traditional Omani dhow characterised by a high transom stern and a low curving stem, the head of which is usually painted white with a black tip. Used for cargo and passengers, and for pearling. Size widely variable, averaging approx 25 m. Closely related to the šūʕī fishing vessel. The Dhofari stitched sanbūq is also known as kambārī.
Triangular-shaped silver ornament with chains, bells and dangles. Worn by married Dhofari women as a weight for the headscarf.

General term for robe or dress. A specific term for the traditional women's dress of Dhofar, comprising two rectangular panels, the rear panel trailing on the ground behind the wearer. Also used to refer to the mesh overcloak worn by women of the Sharqiyah.
Yellow-orange dye derived from Flemingia rhodocarpa or Flemingia grahamiana, a plant indigenous to Dhofar and Yemen. Used to stain the skin and to dye cloth.
Basket for general use, made from plaited palm leaflet. Used in Dhofar for the storage and transportation of dried sardines.
Silver toe ring with a square front flanked by vertical ridges. Worn by women in Dhofar.
Curved dagger worn by Jibbali men of Dhofar, with similarities to the ḫanǧar of northern Oman and the Yemeni ǧanbiyyah.
Palm-frond leaflet. Used for the making of basketry and cordage. Jibbali var ḫiz [not listed separately].
The shells of any of various indigenous species of cowrie (genus Cypraea). Used to decorate traditional boats in Musandam and portable baby-cots (markab) in Dhofar.
General term for a drinking bowl. The term is used in Dhofar to refer to terracotta water-storage bowls with woven palm lids. In Musandam the term also refers to milk bowls.
Boring tool, used in the production of lashed date-frond panels (daʕan). Also used as a general term for red pigment used on pottery in Musandam.
min hādī? wer ist diese? min hādēle wer sind diese? min hinnāk wer ist dort?
mū hāde? was ist das? mū ismek? wie heisst du? mū hādēla il-ʕašyā? was sind dies für Sachen?

lex: fī ēyyi bildān yiṯmru hadēle iš-šigār

def: mū min iḍ-ḍurs? mū min iḍ-ḍurūs? mū min il-kitāb? mū min il-kitub? mū min il-ḥurma? mū min il-ḥarīm? mū min in-nās? mū min il-gōḫa ḥālbis? mū min ilḫēl tibġā tyrkub inte fōqahu? mū min il-faṣl naḥnu fīhi? mū min il-kitub tʕallemt inte fīhi?

lex: qatel, qatlet, qatelt, qatelti, qatelt, qatlu, qateltu, qatelna
fehem, fehmet, fehemt, fehemti, fehemt, fehmu, fehemtu, fehemna
šarab, šarbet, šarabt, šarabti, šarabt, šarbu, šarabtu, šarabna
yaqtyl, taqtyl, taqtyl, tqatli, aqtyl, yiqatly, tqatly, naqtyl
yiktub, tiktub, tiktub, tkitbi, ektub, yikitbu, tkitbu, niktub
yirkeb, tirkeb, tirkeb, trikbi, arkeb, yirikbu,trikbu,nirkeb
yifhem, tifhem, tifhem, tfehmi, efhem, yifehmu, tfehmu, nifhem
yyqṭaʕ, tyqṭaʕ, tyqṭaʕ, tquṭʕi, aqṭaʕ, yiquṭʕu, tquṭʕu, nyqṭaʕi
lī, lek, liš, lehu, leha, lena
fōq hēn il-ḫēl tibġa tyrkub inte
